abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Enterprise and Financial Sector
            Adjustment Loan in Slovenia. The overall rating of the
            project is satisfactory; and the performance of Bank and the
            borrower is also satisfactory. Slovenia has made good
            progress in transforming its economy to a market-based
            system. Growth has been achieved in a stable macroeconomic
            environment and in conjunction with considerable
            microeconomic reforms. As a result of the privatization of
            socially-owned enterprises, which is nearly completed, and
            the entry of new private enterprise, the private sector is
            now estimated to make up about 50 percent of GDP. Some of
            the main lessons that can be drawn from this project are: a)
            Comprehensiveness of Program Design - The Enterprise and
            Financial Assistance Loan (EFSAL) was designed as a
            comprehensive reform package addressing interrelated
            macroeconomic, enterprise, and banking sector problems
            within a single consistent framework. Concerns were raised
            during the preparation and implementation of the EFSAL
            regarding the broad scope of the program. However,
            experience has shown in Slovenia as well as in other
            transition countries that consistency and coherence of
            macroeconomic, enterprise, and banking sector reforms are
            essential for the success in achieving the reform
            objectives. This was particularly relevant in Slovenia
            because the EFSAL program was the first comprehensive
            medium-term program for economic transformation following
            independence. The scope of the program and some of its main
            elements such as bank restructuring was replicated in
            subsequent programs in the other countries in the region. b)
            Ambitious Time-frame - Any program of major adjustments of
            the enterprise and banking sectors addresses the core
            foundation of the economic system. It should therefore be
            expected that such reforms generate wide-ranging debate on
            policy, institutional, and legislative issues. This was
            particularly true in the case of Slovenia, a newly
            independent country which was building its democratic
            institutions, its public administration, and in which there
            has been a tradition of consensus building.
